3.text:
I didn't sleep at all last night my throat
is just on fire my skin's hurting and I generally

16.text: I'm not looking forward to hiking 16km today

52.text:
Reaching the Kungsleden is an adventure in
itself, with the first leg of the journey

56.text: involving a flight from London to Stockholm

62.text:
Located in the northernmost section of Sweden,
in the heart of Lapland, there are numerous

66.text:
methods for reaching Abisko which is the start
of the trail in the north

70.text:
We'd chosen to catch the overnight train which
had us sharing a 6 berth cabin with a young

75.text: German couple who were also heading to Abisko

98.text:
It was autumn 2014 when we met Cody and Justyna
in the Lofoten Islands of northern Norway.

104.text:
A chance conversation through Twitter turned
into a campfire on the beach and it was six

108.text:
months later in Germany when we hashed out
plans to all walk the trail together.

114.text:
The Kungsleden is one of the most well known
trails in Sweden, with many people exploring

119.text: it during the summer and winter seasons.

130.text:
We've just arrived at Abisko mountain station.
The weather's really nice, it's nice and cool

135.text:
- brilliant hiking weather. And yeah, I can't
wait to get on the trail I'm feeling surprisingly

141.text: fresh after a 20 hour train journey.

156.text:
15? I wish it was thirteen but oh well what
can you do? [laughs]

171.text:
[laughs] Oh wow. Wow.
Are you gonna survive?

177.text:
The Swedish Tourist Association created the
trail in the early 1900s as a way to bring

181.text:
more people into the last largest remaining
wilderness in Europe. Gradually adding more

186.text:
sections to the trail as years went by, until
it reached its current length of 440km in

210.text:
It's possible to hike the trail with limited
food during the open season to lighten your

214.text:
load, as many cabins have small shops with
basic supplies which are run by the hut wardens

218.text:
during the open season. This method can be
quite costly, which is why many people hike

223.text:
with 5 to 7 days worth of food at a time and
can instead buy luxury items - such as coke

228.text: or extra chocolate - from the cabin stores.

232.text:
We're in Abiskojaure which is the first hut
of the trail, 15km in and totally knackered

242.text:
STF has 21 cabins placed from Abisko to Hemavan
along the Kungsleden. Providing shelter for

247.text:
a small fee with shared accommodation, water
sources and camping spots. Many also have

252.text:
saunas and small shops which is a real benefit
after a long days hiking.

271.text:
Slept really well last night, all of us did
I think, even though I was up 'til quite late

277.text:
watching the northern lights was just incredible
to see that on our first night on the Kungsleden.

286.text:
A 20km day to Alesjaure is accomplished with
300m elevation, on towards a windswept alpine

293.text:
and blueberry infused meadow with views overlooking
the Norwegian peaks over the border.

305.text:
The possibility of completing the entire trail
during September looked thin. A number of

310.text:
people had told us we may need to step off
the trail at Kvikkjokk - halfway through the

332.text:
Alesjaure has a fantastic water system, drawing
water up the hill from the river to allow

337.text: hikers easy access to fresh water.

369.text:
We began the slow and steady ascent towards
the highest area of the entire trail, arriving

374.text:
at the small cabin at Tjaktja. Snow still
clinging to the mountainside in large quantities,

379.text: adding a chill to the air.

400.text:
So we just arrived and had lunch at the hut.
It's our third day on the Kungsleden and it

407.text:
was really nice weather again today, which
was brilliant. We've got our own room which

412.text:
is amazing so we should be able to get a really
nice nights sleep. And down here, we've got

419.text:
some wood. There's a woodburner just behind
me which is really cool, keep the room nice

424.text:
and toasty throughout the night. The weather's
not too good tomorrow, it's forecast to rain

431.text:
so we've just to bear that in mind and wrap
up warm.

438.text:
Everyone contributes to the huts by chopping
wood, sweeping the floors, and fetching fresh

451.text:
Reaching a height of 1,100m, Tjaktja pass
is the highest point along the Kungsleden.

457.text:
From its summit there are majestic views of
Tjaktja valley, a beautiful area which will

460.text: take a couple of days to walk through.

464.text:
At around 32km long the glacial valley is
well loved by many as impressive mountains

469.text:
line the sides, waterfalls make their way
into the meandering river, and the cabin settlement

474.text:
at Salka is situated 12km from Tjaktja with
reindeer grazing on the hillside.

486.text:
The thing is though like when you've been
hiking for four days, and you get a big meal

491.text:
like this, it just makes all the difference
because you just feel powered, ready for the

497.text:
So what are you gonna eat in 26 more days?
[laughs]

511.text:
The northernmost section of the trail is by
far the most popular, and thousands of people

516.text:
each year split off the Kungsleden at Singi
to venture past - and ascent if they feel

520.text:
up to it - Mount Kebnekaise, Swedens highest
mountain. From here they end their journey

525.text:
at Nikkaluokta. Passing Singi the crowds noticeably
thin, and continue to do so for the remainder

534.text:
My legs are in agony today it's so hard on
this rocky path it's just relentless, but

541.text:
erm, hopefully the next hut is about a kilometre
away, we still can't see it but really fingers

547.text: crossed we haven't got too much to go!

551.text:
I had begun to have troubles of tendonitis
in my hip, an old injury which had flared

555.text:
up after a few days, and unfortunately running
out of painkillers there was nothing to numb

656.text: By now we'd covered roughly 73km of the trail, and even though it was only a 9km hike from Kaitumjaure to Teusajaure

664.text: it was taking its toll on Theo who was battling a fluey cold

672.text: I'm not looking forward to hiking 16km today.

680.text:
There are 7 boat crossings included along
the length of the Kungsleden, with the first

684.text:
you reach coming from the north at Teusajaure.
There's the option to row, but that cuts into

688.text:
your hiking time and if you're feeling the
effects of illness like Theo, then it's worth

692.text:
the luxury to pay for a ride and preserve
your energy levels.

701.text:
Panoramic glacial views of Sarek National
Park come into view across the plateau - a

705.text: glimpse of the wildest part of Europe.

710.text:
After the steep descent towards Vakkotavare
it's a 30km bus ride to Kebnats on the shore

715.text:
of lake Langas. For 70krones you can bypass
a days trek along the roadside which everyone

782.text:
It's a 10 minute ferry ride across the lake
to the mountain station at Saltoluokta. Here

787.text:
lies a popular gateway for many to enter Sarek
National Park, an area with no designated

806.text:
Saltoluokta is the first place to recharge
camera gear, and we made the most out of the

814.text:
You've got to keep the blisters clean, otherwise
they get infected. And I'll be in pain

820.text: Well, a lot more pain than I'm already in

824.text:
The impressive lodge was built in 1918 and
offers hikers the chance to restock their

828.text:
supplies for the coming days in their well
stocked shop.

861.text:
Views overlooking Sjofallsdalen provided a
stunning backdrop as we left Saltoluokta,

866.text:
with 66km to go until our halfway point at
Kvikkjokk. A late summer seemed to have descended

872.text: upon us, so we took our time to reach Sitojaure.

933.text:
So we're about 9km into the hike today, we've
got another 11 to go, we've just took some

939.text:
shelter in the wind in this little cabin,
which is really cool. We cooked a Mug Shot,

945.text:
and now we're gonna head off, should take
about two hours to get to our destination

949.text:
tonight. Hopefully some northern lights action
tonight as well. That would be really nice.

957.text:
With only 11km to go I had to slow it down
with my tendonitis, the pain was unbearable.

963.text:
Once I reached the cabin I immediately went
to bed, whilst Theo joined Justyna as she

967.text:
bathed her sore ankle in the lake. Her injury
seemed to be worsening as the days went by,

971.text:
slowing her down and having to share more
of her load with Cody.

999.text:
Sitojaure has a private boat service run by
a local family. But there's also the option

1006.text:
I was here 2 years and a day ago, same weather
perfect conditions, I thought it would be

1013.text:
cool to shoot a timelapse as I rowed the boat
over the lake. Except for my camera didn't

1018.text:
quite agree - nor did the boat - and my camera
decided to go swimming in the lake. Which

1023.text:
resulted in the end of that trip. Hopefully
this time I'll make up for it with perfect

1028.text:
northern lights with my tent on the top of
Skierfe, and that'll be worth the $5000 price

1034.text: tag that it cost me last time.

1115.text:
Considering it's a 4km journey the 200 krone
price tag is worth it if it means less time

1120.text:
spent on the water and the opportunity for
some insider knowledge.

1146.text:
We'd been informed by the boat operator of
the Sami herding an enormous reindeer herd

1150.text:
down to lower ground that day, so we made
our way swiftly to the plateau to find a spot

1160.text:
Hot, sweaty, and I'm looking forward to a
Coke!

1198.text:
We were just surrounded by a thousand reindeer.
Sitting on top of a pretty big rock but could

1203.text: have been a little bit bigger!

1208.text: Yeah there's usually a few rogues.

1212.text:
Yeah! We saw the whole thing it looked very
dare devil on that rock. How close did they

1220.text: Really? It looked amazing from over here.

1222.text:
Still on a high from the incredible sight
they'd witnessed, Theo and Cody took a popular

1226.text:
detour from the trail to the famous Skierfe
with stunning views over Rapadalen.

1233.text:
Everyone's told us it's impossible to camp
up here because it's too rocky, but I think

1238.text:
I've found a few spots that should be do-able.
If you're in a 1 person tent there's lots

1244.text:
of places, but two person tent might be a
little tricky. Otherwise find a nice flat

1249.text:
rock and have an open air bivvy, and watch
the northern lights overhead from the warmth

1254.text:
of the sleeping bags. Don't think life gets
much better than that.

1259.text:
Think right here. Little bit up, couple rocks,
but think it's gonna be our best bet for our

1275.text:
The lack of water sources within the surrounding
area combined with a rocky landscape makes

1280.text:
camping out atop Skierfe a challenge in itself.
But it's undoubtedly worth it.

1285.text:
Justyna and I had carried on towards the cabin
at Akste, with a swollen ankle and tendonitis

1290.text:
between us it was vital we rest as much as
possible or else risk having to drop out.

1297.text:
Looking good. Home for the night. A little
bit crooked home, but home. Which side do

1323.text:
Do you want to roll onto me or be rolled on
by me?

1333.text:
We got cous cous tonight - pretty much every
night - pretty bored of it right now to be

1338.text: honest. But it gets me full.

1377.text: That ain't much for the morning.

1397.text:
It was a bit windy last night, I'm almost
out of water - two sips left to hike the 6km

1403.text:
back to the hut. Got a bit of a head cold,
but yeah it's worth being up. Wouldn't trade

1424.text:
Theo and Cody joined us in Akste, where they
had a chance to catch up on the little sleep

1428.text:
they'd had the night before after watching
the Northern Lights atop Skierfe.

1442.text:
1km from Akste lies lake Laiture which we
crossed on the last operational day of the

1447.text:
STF motorboat. There is now only 7 days left
until the rowboats are pulled from the lakes

1452.text:
for winter storage, meaning our group must
reach Hornavan on the outskirts of Jakkvikk

1457.text:
- roughly 117km away - before then where the
only option of crossing the lake is by rowboat.

1464.text:
The journey over the lake is the fourth boat
crossing along the trail and with Sarek looming

1469.text: in the background it's one of the most stunning.

1494.text:
It's a strenuous hike towards Pårte but it's
also through a thin stretch of the eastern

1498.text:
section of Sarek National Park. Fields of
blueberries surround the path, we even saw

1503.text:
evidence of a nearby Brown Bear after passing
its scat on the trail.

1519.text:
We didn't know it at the time, but these would
be our last days hiking together.

1530.text:
So after a 
long discussion yesterday evening, Cody and
Justyna have come to the decision that it's

1537.text:
probably best that they end the trail here
due to Justynas ongoing leg injury. She's

1544.text:
been struggling for a while and can't carry
on any further, so they're gonna stop here,

1550.text:
we're gonna carry on, and we're excited to
get to Hemavan eventually! We're nearly halfway

1557.text:
and can't wait to see what the south has to
offer.

1560.text:
Other than the prospect of an early onset
of winter, injury was the second biggest factor

1565.text:
in ending the trail prematurely. It was with
a heavy heart that we parted ways, as Cody

1570.text:
was struggling with the weight of his pack
and Justyna's ankle had worsened. They opted

1574.text:
to take a bus to Ammarnäs 166km away, have
some rest, and possibly rejoin from there

1580.text:
to complete the southernmost section of the
trail.

1606.text:
The Kungsleden begins again on the other side
of Saggat lake with the only option across

1610.text:
via a private boat service which also offers
tours of 
the area.

1704.text:
After being roped into an extensive 45 minute
tour of the delta we finally made our way

1709.text:
into the section of the Kungsleden dubbed
the toughest. 166km with no STF cabins means

1716.text: that a tent is a necessity.

1743.text:
Leaving Kvikkjokk it seemed everyones concerns
over the onset of an early winter were squashed,

1748.text:
as autumn still reined high in the mountains.
The possibility of completing the entire Kungsleden

1754.text:
trail were now high and with that thought
running through our minds it gave us a new

1778.text:
Even though there's a, this is a really nice
shelter we've had a late lunch and there's

1782.text:
still quite a few hours of daylight left so
we're just gonna carry on because we want

1786.text:
to reach the boat before the really bad weather
hits on Friday and the boat are getting pulled

1791.text:
on Friday or Saturday anyway so we're keen
to just get there, get it over with!

1800.text: After another 10-15km we set up camp next to a river

1804.text: relieved to have made it so far that day

1806.text: and to escape into the tent just before the rain started

1858.text:
This looks like a pretty good spot. Good to
see the suns made an appearance after it's

1863.text: been pissing it down all day.

1886.text:
It's probably like one of the best smashes
we've had, it tastes really really smashy.

1894.text:
The butter and potato is very strong in this
one. You start to notice these things when

1902.text:
you've had a couple of different varieties.
I miss vegetables so much, I find myself thinking

1909.text:
about like salad and vegetables when I'm walking
along sometimes. Sometimes, all the time!

1920.text:
Just like peas, potatoes, carrots, peppers,
sweet potato, mushrooms, onions, garlic just

1937.text:
fresh stuff. Living out of packets is fun
for the first day and then after a while it

1942.text:
gets a bit tedious. But it's all part of the
adventure.

1947.text:
My feet aren't looking too good. The blisters
are just peeling off all over the place. Today

1954.text:
didn't help walking through loads of boggy
areas. Hopefully I can dry them out overnight,

1963.text:
put some fresh socks on in the morning, and
they'll heal up in the next few days.

1970.text:
We're a lot higher up on the top of the mountain
tonight and it's a lot cooler than it was

1976.text:
last night but still not too bad. I've managed
to make a nice little pillow out of this dry-bag

1985.text:
full of clothes, works quite well. I think
it's time to hit the sack.

2011.text:
I didn't sleep at all well last night, I've
got stuff coming out of my ear that I don't

2017.text:
even know what it is. Definitely got a pretty
bad ear infection so I just can't wait to

2024.text: get warm and dry and try and heal.

2037.text:
Theo's cold had begun to transform under the
constant rainfall. With perforated eardrums

2042.text:
his risk of developing an ear infection was
high. A situation which unfortunately seemed

2056.text:
The boats were due to be removed from the
lake on September 20th. It would be a massive

2060.text:
blow if we missed them as the alternative
would require a major trail-less detour to

2070.text:
We were nearing lake Riebnes and picked up
patchy signal allowing us to call the private

2074.text:
boat service in advance to let them know of
our arrival. They'd said we could cross that

2079.text:
afternoon so we had high hopes of possibly
reaching Jakkvikk that evening as we'd read

2083.text:
the trail was only 8km from the other side
of the lake, which also included another lake

2088.text:
crossing of 300m that could only be crossed
by rowboat. Unfortunately our timetable lay

2096.text:
in the hands of the boat driver and we had
a three hour wait in the rain before he arrived.

2101.text:
We're just waiting to get the motorboat to
the other side of this big lake. It's the

2107.text:
last boat we're gonna have to pay to use to
get across on the Kungsleden trail. After

2113.text:
we reach the other side there's then, I think
roughly, about a 8km trek to Jakkvikk but

2119.text:
during that time there's also a 300m rowboat
session as well so it's gonna be a pretty

2124.text:
long day today but we really need to get somewhere
warm because both our shoes are for some reason

2129.text:
absolutely drenched and two days of soggy
feet does not make a happy person. It's just

2136.text:
been raining constantly since we left Kvikkjokk
and this section of the trail that we're on

2143.text:
is the wildest section so there aren't as
many boards and all that kind of luxurious

2149.text:
stuff that there usually is so it's been very
wet going, with the rain on top both of our

2155.text:
waterproof boots are drenched so it's not
been the most comfortable experience, I'm

2161.text:
hoping that after we get to Jakkvikk and we
can dry out that the second half of the wild

2166.text:
section will be more enjoyable and hopefully
even if it does rain our boots will stay dry

2171.text:
this time because it is beautiful when the
clouds clear and you can see your surroundings

2179.text:
but right now you can't even see to the other
side of the lake so I think we've missed a

2183.text:
lot of the beautiful scenery that we could
have seen which is a shame.

2221.text:
The cost to cross the lake is the highest
along the Kungsleden at 350krones each. The

2227.text:
journey is short and the company hostile.
We'd heard from other hikers who'd crossed

2231.text:
the lake coming north that the guy running
the boat here wasn't the nicest and now we

2235.text:
knew why as he ignored us for the full five
minute crossing. Having to wait up to three

2241.text:
hours to cross the lake we had now missed
our opportunity to hike to the open shelter

2245.text: at the next lake crossing 8km away.

2252.text:
The hostel and chance to dry off were still
a day away and after checking our map it turned

2256.text:
out the distance to Jakkvikk was double what
was in the guide we'd been following

2268.text:
I hope it's no t the boat we gotta use! It
doesn't look very rowable.

2279.text:
So because there's only 1 boat on our side
I've gotta row across the lake to the other

2285.text:
side pick up another boat, bring it back,
drop it here then row us both back to the

2292.text:
other side of the lake so 3 times in total.
I'm feeling pretty dizzy, my balance is a

2299.text:
bit off with this ear infection but it doesn't
look too far probably about 300m so it's gotta

2347.text:
So I'm back over this side after towing the
boat over here and we're gonna head off now

2353.text:
because it's just started raining and it's
about to get a lot heavier.

2386.text:
By now we were wet through to our underwear
and had ran out of dry clothes. The desperation

2391.text: to reach a warm shelter was high.

2395.text:
We just saw a moose trotting through the forest
at the edge of the treeline. And, sadly the

2401.text:
moment the camera got pulled out it had vanished.
But it was massive and I can't believe we've

2406.text:
just seen one after being literally in the
middle of nowhere for 3 days and now we're

2410.text:
on a road and there was 1 right there because
we've seen so many moose droppings over the

2418.text:
So the moose that we saw running through the
forest is still in the forest right where

2422.text:
we saw it it's just kind of shaded by some
trees. It's just standing there, not moving

2445.text:
Theo managed to pick up signal
on the outskirts of town, calling the hostel

2449.text:
to check availability. It turned out it was
fully booked.

2457.text:
A stroke of luck saw us staying in a cabin
the kind hostel owner had on his property,

2462.text:
so we spent 2 nights in the town of Jakkvikk
giving us the opportunity to dry out all of

2467.text: our belongings and restock our supplies.

2469.text:
So there's a um, small garage, well normal
sized garage that's got a small supermarket

2476.text:
inside it where we've managed to get food
to last until we reach Ammarnäs, so the general

2483.text:
stuff noodles and things like smash and 3
minute rice like it's pretty bland but it

2494.text:
means that we'll be getting to eat food until
we reach the next place because you need stuff

2501.text:
that's gonna cook fast and not weigh too much
so. But also because we're staying in this

2505.text:
cabin we've got access to an oven and stuff
that we don't usually have, we've decided

2510.text:
to like treat ourselves and get other things
like some waffle mixture, fresh fruit which

2520.text: is gonna be amazing, and a pizza kit.

2530.text:
Our gear could completely dry out during the
two nights we spent there and a solid days

2533.text: rest made a world of difference for us both.

2537.text:
Spirits buoyed with the extra rest and thorough
drying, restocked bags and lots of ibuprofen,

2542.text:
we made our way to Adolfström, our last dip
into a town before being completely cut off

2547.text:
again. From Jakkvikk onwards there are shelters
and cabins along the rest of the trail, so

2551.text:
if we could avoid tent time then we would
at all costs.

2558.text:
We spent last night in Adolfström in this
perfect little cabin, it had everything we

2564.text:
need but it's very compact! Today we've got
23km to do, then the next day 25km, and then

2574.text:
the day after that we arrive in Ammarnäs
which is I think a 21km hike. So a tough 3

2582.text: days ahead of us but we're feeling good.

2585.text:
The small town of Adolfström is a 27km hike
from Jakkvikk with a small shop to grab any

2591.text:
extras for the next 71km before the town of
Ammarnäs.

2611.text:
It was well over a kilometre back. I went
round the corner, I was about to give up,

2618.text:
and there it was lying on the path. I'm glad
I've been reunited with it, because no one

2625.text:
needs to see my hair in the state that it's
in at the moment.

2644.text:
When we came round the corner and saw this
cabin I was just so happy because along the

2651.text:
route we spoke to loads of different people
and everyone seems to have a different idea

2656.text:
of what this cabin is. Loads of people have
said it's just a wind shelter, you know it

2662.text:
might not even have a door, and all these
kind of different things about this cabin

2667.text:
and we got here and it's really nice and it's
perfect to sleep in so I've just got the fire

2672.text:
going, hopefully we can dry our boots out
before the morning because I'm not a fan of

2678.text:
putting wet boots on and I've had to do it
a lot recently. Wet socks, wet boots, no fun.

2693.text:
I love being in a tent but to have actual
walls around you is a lot nicer, especially

2714.text:
Ammarnäs lay a days hike away, and the need
for rest pressed heavily on us. Theo's ear

2719.text:
infection still troubled him with fluid constantly
seeping out day or night.

2724.text:
My hip problems were getting increasingly
worse, and together we longed for a days rest,

2729.text:
a shower, and the possibility of some food
other than 3 minute rice.

2740.text:
Justyna had been in touch, informing us they'd
journey from Ammarnäs a week before. The

2744.text:
chance of crossing the finish line together
now was no longer an option.

2748.text: After the past tough 10 days we expected the last stretch to be a lot easier

2758.text:
With 78km to go until the finish line in Hemavan
and a few days rest in Ammarnäs, we entered

2764.text:
the last stretch with a renewed sense of vigour.
The end was in our sights and winter was beginning

2771.text:
The area was outstanding, and we were ecstatic
with the clear views after being covered by

2776.text:
clouds and fog for so long. Wide open spaces
and golden forests broke up the landscape,

2781.text:
if only we could have seen what awaited us
in the coming days.

2806.text:
Thinking we were the only people around, we
were in for a wonderful surprise as we met

2810.text:
two local fishermen staying in their ancestral
family cabins for the season at lake Tarnasjö.

2816.text:
They'd kindly offered us some freshly caught
fish, along with some instant mashed potato.

2886.text: With the amenities in the cabin being a frying pan and some salt,we cooked up a meal we never dreamed we'd

2898.text:
They're cooking perfectly on this woodburner.
I've never really cooked fish like this before

2904.text:
so I just literally chopped the heads off
and just whacked them in the pan. But they

2909.text:
smell real good so as along as the meat is
cooked I don't see why they won't taste good

2914.text:
either. Especially with the mash that the
man gave us as well which is really sweet.

2920.text:
This is like a proper, proper dinner which
I've, just I've missed so much since we've

2926.text: been hiking for nearly a month now.

2934.text:
Leaving Tarnasjö there are a network of bridges
spanning the Tarnasjö archipelago midway

2957.text:
By now all the huts were closed for winter,
but there's always a room left open for anyone

2961.text:
hiking out of season. It was a stark contrast
to the busy huts of the north, especially

2966.text:
as we hadn't seen another person on the trail
since Kvikkjokk - 10 days earlier.

2976.text:
I'm so happy that you can't record the smell
of my feet right now.

2984.text:
It dawned on me today that we've done already
like 400 and something kilometres and it's

2990.text:
just catching up now suddenly just feel the
exhaustion of 4 weeks of non-stop hiking and

2998.text:
I'm just totally shattered. Like, when we
started the southern section I remember saying

3003.text:
to Theo 'it's gonna be so easy we're only
doing 14km a day or whatever', today was the

3009.text:
hardest 14km my feet are just broken I have
no energy. I'm just, I'm so tired. The Kungsleden

3019.text:
is now taking its energy toll.
I need to sleep. And I need to eat, I just

3047.text:
We haven't seen anyone hiking for nearly 2
weeks which is kind of strange really because

3053.text:
in the north section we see people everyday.
And today I woke up, rushed to the window

3059.text:
and had a look out to see what the weather
was like and there's a lot of fresh snow on

3064.text:
the mountaintops which kind of means the weather's
changing and the seasons are changing and

3072.text:
this is kind of the last time that you'll
be able to hike the trail. We're very late

3078.text:
in the season to be doing it and I think we're
definitely the last people who are gonna complete

3103.text:
It wouldn't be fair to have a breezy last
two days along the trail, and with a blizzard

3106.text:
pushing against us to Viterskalstugan it was
a reminder of the harsh environment that we'd

3111.text:
be journeying through and how quickly the
weather can change in the mountains.

3121.text:
It's coming down pretty hard, this isn't very
nice. Hopefully we'll get to the emergency

3129.text: shelter in the next few kilometres.

3133.text:
We'd made it into our final valley and our
harshest weather along the trail so far. Completely

3139.text:
exposed it was a welcoming sight to spot the
emergency cabin mid-way to our final cabin

3143.text: on this journey to hide in for a while.

3150.text:
That was relentless the whole way we had rain,
sleet, and snow in our face. It was pretty

3158.text:
hard work plus the wind was coming at us so
it was a lot harder to walk but I did kind

3165.text:
of enjoy it as well because coming into the
valley there was, there's fresh snow on the

3170.text:
peaks and the mountains either side it was
really beautiful. Also we stopped off at the

3175.text:
emergency cabin so that give us a bit of rest
from the snow and the wind and the rain and...yeah

3184.text:
allowed us to just have a break, get some
chocolate down us and then head on and get

3189.text:
to this cabin. And now we've only got 11km
to go until we've completed the Kungsleden.

3202.text:
I've never appreciated the woodburners in
any of the cabins as much as I have today.

3207.text:
It's gonna dry our clothes out hopefully,
warm us up, and we can cook on it later.

3219.text:
The snowfall grew heavier and heavier and as we
went to bed it had already completely blanketed

3224.text:
the landscape. We were preparing ourselves
for a whiteout the following morning.

3235.text:
A fierce storm had descended upon the valley
in the night, rattling the cabin and flinging

3239.text:
the door wide open. The extreme weather called
for full body armour along the last 11km before

3283.text:
Insanely strong wind and hail battered us
body and spirit, it felt as if we would never

3288.text:
make it to Hemavan. Our GoPro took the full
brunt of the weather, but the stormy horizon

3293.text: had a beautiful side to it too.

3319.text:
And there is was, the final few steps were
unbelievable. After 440km through arctic Sweden,

3325.text: on day 30, we'd finally made it.
